data.title: ‘The Offer’ is Hearts Of Darkness as Muppet comedy

data.text: Clint Eastwood announces the winner of the Oscar for Best Picture… it’s The Godfather! Al Ruddy jumps from his seat and parades to the stage, a mountain of applause on either side of him, a spotlight lighting his path. It’s a Chariots of Fire moment, a triumph for artistic integrity and creative willpower. And it’s hard not to laugh. If you check out real footage of Ruddy’s acceptance speech at the 1973 ceremony, where Coppola’s film competed with Cabaret for the main awards and Best Actor winner Marlon Brando protested by having a Native American activist accept his award, the real Ruddy is a greasy little goblin practically wagging his tongue at the honour. He isn’t, by any means, the suave if perennially cocky Miles Teller, who takes centre stage in this 10-part Paramount+ miniseries, a last minute replacement for original Ruddy casting Armie Hammier, who’s services were no longer required after some… chewy… headlines. Teller makes for a great lead in a show about 70s Hollywood, a period to which his star persona is something of a throwback, but if we were casting based on resemblance, Ruddy would be played by — absolute best case scenario — a Culkin. The Offer isn’t about accurate depiction of the making of The Godfather so much as weaving a heroic narrative and cement Ruddy’s legacy as one of cinema’s greatest producers. Whether he is, I’m not sure, but he’s still alive, and he…
